description.text: Beloved Plowie/Dozer from the FRC Game Animations

Needs:
-6x axle and wheel
-2x eyeball, iris, pupil and link
-1x everything else Note: print ChassisR upsidedown from the default, was just the way SolidWorks created the file when I sliced it in two Assembly is pretty straightforward. clip link/blade onto chassis only after everything else is glued I found the axles needed a little sanding (I used 100 grit) and the holes in the chassis needed cleaning with a round file.
Glue with quality superglue. I used loctite gel. I printed from a PrintrBot Maker using the Simple MtlConfig, but with honeycomb infill at 60%

comments.text: i flipped some pieces
comments.author: bigibomb

comments.text:
From Dave Lavery (Dozer's creator)
"Dozer's name is "Dozer." It always has been. It is not, and never has been "Plowie." Plowie is his younger second cousin, who just happens to be a Tonka road-grader. Dozer gets quite offended when he is confused with Plowie. He then goes off and sulks in the corner for the entire afternoon, and it takes an enormous amount of coaxing to get him to settle down and play nicely with the other construction equipment. So please, for the sake of small blue bulldozers everywhere, let's put an end to this Dozer/Plowie confusion, and just use his proper name."

title: Arm Jig For Delta-Pi Reprap 3D Printer

description.text:
This a jig that I made up for accurately gluing the arm sections of the Delta-Pi Reprap 3D Printer. 
It is made up of layers of 3mm MDF, laser cut to house the pivot sections, with a base part to set the length. 
All the layers are held together with 8 1/8"x25mm bolts. 
NOTE: In the picture the bottom layers are acrylic but that is not required it was just what material I had laying around.
Fairly self explanatory, There are 2 layers of the pivot cut-outs on each side attached to 2 layers of base plate.

comments.text: You have the perfect alignment holes already at the ends of your rod.  Simply cut 2 holes in a piece of material the right distance apart and thread a bolt into it and tighten it down.  Then you simply place the printed piece over it.

title: K8200/3Drag GT2 X Belt Mount with easy Tension - Upgrade

description.text:
This simple construction are for upgrading your K8200/3Drag to GT2 belt on X axis.
It is a direct replacement, reusing the original mount screw and holes, adding the missing belt tension. For complete upgrade of X axis to GT2, you need:
  • GT2 6mm belt (mine is from ebay)
  • GT2 pulley for motor (20 teeth and 5mm motor hole)
  • The printed parts (2x wedge + mount left + mount right + clamp)
  • Two M3x30mm screws
  • Two M3 nuts
    • Assembly as shown on pictures. For the Y axis use K8200/3Drag GT2 Y Belt Mount with easy Tension - Upgrade

comments.text: Hi - printed well (wedges needed a little fettling) works a treat – had to use the original aluminium clamp as a spacer under the RHS to lift it slightly to get the belts parallel – thanks for a great design.
comments.author: Barnabybear

comments.text: Thank you for your tip with the spacer. I think this would make it possible to use a 16 tooth GT2 pulley on the motor and keep the original bearing idler. Thanks.
comments.author: Barnabybear

comments.text:
Hi - correct - I hadn't noticed that it was for the 20 tooth pulley - works great with the 16 if you use the original clamp as a spacer.
Next up is to sort the Y axis – unfortunately I can’t use your design as I don’t have the clearance on the right hand side due to an aluminium brace between the motor and the idler bearing to prevent the carriage bending and misaligning the X axis linear bearings when you tension the belt.

title: Proximity Sensor Holder for Lulzbot Taz - Auto Bed Leveling

description.text:
Proximity sensor holder for Lulzbot Taz that mounts where the fan does. There is a 12mm version and a 16mm version. Which one you need depends on your sensor's diameter. You will need a capacitive proximity sensor if your bed is glass. You could also use a inductive proximity sensor if you have the new version of the PRINTinZ Printer Plate aka Ninja Plate. You'll have to connect the proximity sensor to the z-min endstop on the rambo board and make adjustments to your Marlin firmware. I recommend buying a sensor that will run off 5 volts. You can use a 24v sensor but you'll have to convert the voltage back to 5 volts on the signal wire otherwise you'll fry your Rambo board. There are a bunch of websites online that show you how to do this. UPDATE: I enlarged the hole for the proximity sensor by .5mm. The old files worked but you had to screw the proximity sensor into the hole because it was a tight fit. The new files should fix this problem. A lot of people are wondering which sensors to use so here are some that will work with just a glass bed:
18mm Proximity Sensor-
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008MU0CCG/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=211189&creative=373489&creativeASIN=B008MU0CCG&link_code=as3&tag=techinc0a-20&linkId=MJ7NRDGJCEE35WZ7 12mm Proximity Sensor- http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008MU0G9A/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=211189&creative=373489&creativeASIN=B008MU0G9A&link_code=as3&tag=techinc0a-20&linkId=4N7KHY3CJ3JBIZR3 These will work if you have a metal bed or the PRINTinZ Plate: 18mm Proximity Sensor - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008FZC8F2/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=211189&creative=373489&creativeASIN=B008FZC8F2&link_code=as3&tag=techinc0a-20&linkId=UG6ZVLXPOYBSRNLY 12mm Proximity Sensor - http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B008MU0G9A/ref=as_li_tl?ie=UTF8&camp=211189&creative=373489&creativeASIN=B008MU0G9A&link_code=as3&tag=techinc0a-20&linkId=5YPRS64DNCNU7HAD

comments.text: Whats the best way to go about wiring this?
comments.author: TechsavvyCNC

comments.text: You should connect the brown wire to +, the blue wire to - and the black wire to signal on the z-min endstop connection on the RAMBO.  After it's connected enter gcode M119 with the sensor away from the bed. If it shows triggered you'll have to switch the logic in Marlin. If M119 say's that it is open, put the proximity sensor close to something metal and do M119 again it should say triggered, if not, then it's not getting enough power and you'll have to connect the sensor to 12 or 24 volts and use a voltage divider or LM7805 for the signal wire to RAMBO.
comments.author: paintlax

title: Fisher & Paykel Dishwasher tray lock add on

description.text:
This little yellow block slips in behind the hindged gray caps on the dishwasher rails to prevent them opening accidentally which would allow the tray to slide off the rails unintentionally possibly resulting in broken dishes.  
The opening of the rails by themselves seems to a a minor design flaw in this model dishwasher but this lock prevents unintentional removal of the tray  
There is a left and a right one.  They are easy to remove if you need to slide the tray right out to alter its height.  
This should work for all F&P dishwashers that use the same hindged rail ends.  Mine is a model DW60CE.
Print tray_lock.stl in its default orientation and it does not need support.  I suggest ABS or another high temperature capable plastic as PLA is likley to soften  at typical dishwasher temperatures.

remixed_from.author: mrice
remixed_from.title: Direct drive extruder for Wilson or Prusa i3 rework

title: Stepper mounted extruder cable harness strain relief

description.text:
I designed this for use with Marty Rice's awesome Direct Drive Extruder which I have installed on my 2nd P3Steel, but it can probably be used for many other extruder setups. Simple fact is, there is a thick bunch of electrical wires that come out of the extruder, go around the top of the printer and then down to the RAMPS electronics at the back of the printer. All this moves repeatedly left and right together with the X-carriage and common sense dictates that a strain relief is required to avoid wiring fatigue (breakages, short-circuits) and the usual disastrous consequences. And it makes things look a little less messy!
I have designed this strain relief so that it is very easy to install even after everything is in place. It requires one long and two short nylon ties, the long one goes through the strain relief part itself and around the stepper and the two shorter ones are tightened around the cable harness. Update 26/01/2015: I have uploaded Version 2 of this part. It differs from the original by having a longer arm that bends outwards providing an extra clearance to avoid interfering with the X-axis idler end assembly when the X-carriage reaches the edge of the heated bed. The code is also more modular. OpenSCAD sources are included so both designs can be further remixed.
Printed in PLA with 35% infill. The short overhangs are at 45 degrees and should not be a problem.

title: Gulf of Mexico - Dual Color
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Topography and bathymetry of the Gulf of Mexico at 3x vertical exaggeration in a dual-color extrusion. One STL file for above sea level, another below sea level. Derived from STRM30_Plus topography/bathymetry (http://topex.ucsd.edu/WWW_html/srtm30_plus.html). Original source was here, but link seems to be down: http://gcoos.tamu.edu/products/topography/Introduction.html I thought it made more sense to have the colors run throughout the model, rather than putting sea level topography on top as another layer.

Printed with a raft, two shells, and a 15% infill.  Infill helps with both structural strength and to provide enough support for the flat areas of the topography.  
Pictured model printed on a FlashForge Creator Pro with Hatchbox ABS filament in blue and green at .2 mm.  
Printing just the bathymetry looks very cool, too!

title: Tape Tap v2 - The Evil Twin

description.text:
Now with improved grip control and added slicing edges.  Tape beware, your time has come!
Unless you own a fancy tape dispenser; you only have two options with tape. Either fold the end over and discard that piece when you need a new length. Or you can orbit the tape repeatedly, using eyes and fingernails to locate and pry up the tape end. I give you option three, the Tape Tap. Adhere the tape end to this tap and save yourself some trouble.

• Use SketchUp to push/pull to your desired tape width. Ideally the Tape Tap v2 will be a little bit wider than the tape you are tapping. The added serrations are approximately 10mm in width; so they shouldn't give you any trouble in sizing the Tape Tap v2.

  • Print and clean.

  • Tap your tape. When you use the tape, tap it with the Tape Tap v2 at the desired length. Use the top serration to tear the tape over the tap. Or use the Tape Tap v2 and its bottom serration for all your tape tearing tool tasks. For storage, lay the roll on it's side with the thumb grip facing up.

  • Do something incredible with the 5 to 10 seconds you save, next time you use the tape. Note, time spent applying bandages to finger cuts must be subtracted from overall time saved.
    • Post Print Note - No issues printing, it was fast and flat. I had to file out and sharpen both sets of teeth at the current size. I don't know how much tape you'll get through before the teeth are dull, but I doubt your fingers are in much danger. Happy Printing ~ GearsOfWow

comments.text: Tape Tap is Totally Tops.

comments.text: This is a new way to make what I used CNC to do several years ago: http://e-dot.comhttp://e-dot.com . I would have been pretty excited back then about desktop 3D printing but the materials, speed and cost still make CNC, metal forming, casting etc. more marketable if you need to crank out hundreds of objects a week. By now I'm so far along with learning more traditional methods and inventing all manner of tweaks that the raw look of 3D printed (or laser cut wood or acrylic) parts doesn't excite my interest. I'd want ridiculous speed, three colors of metal, transparency, rubber, surface imagery in full color, etc.

I was sick of my filament being piled up on top of each one so I made this simple shelf stand. I have seen lots of on the wall hooks but most mean that the filament is out of the box and open to the elements. This way I can keep all my Filament in its box with a dessicant pack and it stays free from water and damp The dowel is a standard 12mm dowel available form any timber merchants or DIY STore.  
The system is great as you can move the shelves up and down for thinner boxes etc.
Drawn on Sketchup using, exported to Cura and printed on an Ultimaker 2 on fast settings.

description.text:
Our heater had to be emptied of some air that prevented the warm water to flow inside. I did not have the right key at hand so I quickly designed one in SketchUp and printed it.  
It's a tight fit, but works. I suppose that most european heaters should be compatible.

Printed it using the following settings on my PrintrBot Simple Metal: Layer height: 0.2
Shell thickness: 1.2 (0.4mm nozzle)
Bottom/Top: 0.4mm
Fill density: 100% (it's so tiny, it does not make any difference)
Adhesion: Used a raft in Cura You might need to rotate the key by 180 degrees. The handle should be on top. You don't need any supports as the inside has a slight angle that should easily print.

description.text: This is Japanese lucky mochi (rice cakes) with the traditional tangerine on top.

The mochi pieces are Johnson Solids, slightly extruded along the z-axis and shelled for material-saving (printed upside down like bowls to avoid the final bridging on the last polygon).  The tangerine is another Johnson solid, slightly shortened on the z-axis.  The leaf is a wedge of an icosidodecahedron (an Archimedean Solid).  These were printed on a MakerBot Replicator Mini, using white, green, and orange filament.

author: GigaGremlin

description.text:
Want to keep your ABS coil dust and jam free? Here is something you can do for cheap and it is stackable for all your various colours!
This spindle came about after finding a Sterilite storage drawer in Walmart that pretty much matched the dimensions for a 5lb coil of ABS that I had.
A bit of foam core board, a 6" lazy susan, a few other simple bits and I was off!
One of the key features that makes this work well for me is that the drawer slides out, and the feed is in the drawer front. Stack several of these with different colours and you are set!

Tools needed:
Hobby razor/exacto knife.
Hot glue gun
Measuring tape
Compass, or a string with pencil and a nail. Materials needed:
Storage drawer that is at least 4.5 to 5 inches high inside, and 12-14" wide.
Foam core(art stores carry it)
6" lazy susan(available at most hardware stores)
4-6' of tubing, the stuff used for installing a fridge with an ice maker.
Anti slip matting, also available at hardware stores. First obtain this sotrage drawer, or any other that is similar in size:
http://www.sterilite.com/SelectProduct.html?id=631&view=0&picture=1&tab=Specifications&ProductCategory=185&section=1 Next take a piece of foam core, or thin plywood, perhaps even cardboard? And make two circles that are about 11.5" is diameter. Next make a strip of foam core that is 4" wide by 17" long. This rectangular strip will become the center piece. On one side of the rectangular piece, score a line every inch across the 4" width until you reach the end. Make sure to cut deep enough to cut through the paper of one side of the foam core, and not into the paper of the other side. You should now be able to snap the score lines and form a round center for the spindle. I sized mine up by placing it inside my still twist tied 5lb roll of ABS. Once you obtain the correct size, cut any additional length so that you can bring the two ends together. Place the coil of ABS on one the circles of foam core that you have cut out and center it as closely as you can, not a big deal if it is off by a little bit. Insert the foam core center piece and fire up your hot clue gun. Join the seam and bottom edge to the circular piece, then let cool for a minute. Take your ABS coil off and place the other circular piece on top, trying to ensure that it is centered as well. Now turn it upside down and trace with a pen or pencil around the circumference of the center of the spool so you end up with a mark that you can cut out. Cut the center our and make sure to undersize it by a few mm. Once you have it roughly the right size slowly make it bigger until you can friction fit it on top with the ABS coil in place. You don't really need to have it secured any stronger as the top piece is just there to prevent the coils from springing up during feeding into the Makerbot. Now take the whole assembly, without the ABS coil and have the bottom circular piece facing up. Place the lazy susan in the center and hot glue it on each of the four corners. Let cool to ensure the glue sets well. I then used some of that anti-slip mat roll stuff that you put in drawers and put that in the bottom of the storage drawer. This was a much simpler way for me to be able to place everything inside without needing to secure it. Center the spool and test that it spins freely. Now take some of the tubing and gauge the length you need by placing your Makerbot on top of the drawer and holding the tube to the front of the drawer and curve it up to where it will feed into the plastruder. Cut it with a hobby knife, the length isn't really that critical. Use a hobby knife to "drill" a hole on one side of the front of the clear drawer. I did mine about in the center vertically so the feed will be even. Make the hole a bit smaller than the tubing so that it take a small amount of force to push it in about an inch. This way it is kept in place and no connectors or anything are needed. Grab the end of the ABS filament on the outside of the coil and feed it into the tube after cutting all the twist ties. You are now done, do a final check before you slide the coil and the assembly in that it roatates nicely. Total cost for me was under $25:
Sterilite drawer $10
Refrigerator tubing $2
Foam core was lying around, but about $3 worth?
6" lazy susan was $8
Anti slip matting $.50 I hope to see others who find drawers that might improve on this. Mine bows quite a bit in the center but it doesn't interfere at all.

All files of the Glados lamp have been relocated Makebot always had a few minor issues, but after Stratasys took over things went south quickly. With the Stratasys VS Affinia thing where they sued Affinia with "patents" I have already stopped posting on thingiverse, but with Makerbot trying to patent openly developed technologies, I have lost all of my remaining goodwill towards Makerbot. In light of this recent behavior, I am relocating all my files to my own site: http://ytec3d.com and I will look into posting the designs on another platform as well. I advice everyone to consider if supporting this company is still the right choice for the development of 3D printing like it once was. More things will be relocated when Makerbot decides to make another move.

EDIT: Over a month later and here we are. I have won... I still can't really believe it. First thing first: Thanks! Without you guys this would not have been possible. Not just everyone that voted but also everyone that was supportive, without you I would not have had the energy to finish this thing. Now for the sad part. I have completed this project, and I will not go any further with this project. I have heard amazing ideas from you guys though, so I want to see what everyone else can do with this. So go modify this lamp and make it even more awesome. Amaze me. I have released all of the files in solidworks and step. Feel free to use as long as you credit. Some of the names are in dutch, but changing them would destroy some of the assemblies, so. Good luck everyone, and until my next project. Dragonator out. End of edit See it moving here:
http://youtu.be/QCsiBLz6qqo Go to the instructables page for full instructions on how to make this lamp. You will find a step by step that roughly describes how to make this lamp. http://www.instructables.com/id/EB0KK0JHDOVYWV9/ In the files, there is a stationary and a moving zip file. The stationary arm has no need for servo's and is purely decorative. The moving arm requires 3 micro servo's, one of which needs to be very stong, and a beefy normal servo. To light the lamp, I used 8 3W warm white leds (which in retrospect might have been a little overkill) and one orange 3W led for the eye (only picture in the instructable). The moving arm also uses 2 608 bearings for the arm to rotate. The controller has 4 10k potentiometers to track the position of the mini GlaDOS. I have included a picture of this. If you search ebay for potentiometer, these will show up almost first. The one in the head is a tight fit, but with appropriate force, everything fits. This lamp is entered in several contests on instructables (most importantly the UP! contest). If you like it and have an instructables account, please vote for me in the UP! contest and in the lamps and lights contest. The lamp is designed around the limits of a UP! 3D printer. Special thanks to Almteq in the Netherlands for letting me borrow first one, and then two (TWO) UP! 3D printers (TWO!). Without you guys, this lamp wouldn't have been possible.

author: _LewisA_

title: Remixed Angular Dice Tower, with trays

description.text:
I liked the original Angular Dice Tower, but there were a few bits I wanted to change. So I took the original elegant OpenSCAD code and hammered my own ugly code around it. The things I changed, from the bottom up, were:
  • Added a 'footing'.
  • In ABS the slope of the exit ramp didn't print well, so I filled in that area.
  • On top, I replaced the square entrance funnel with a slightly larger rounded one, eliminating those deadly (and breakable) pointy corners.
  • Extended the height of the divider at the entrance.
  • Now added folding catch trays.
    • Not much, but I like it. EDIT 1/16/15: Ok, so I finally got the catch trays done, and I'm really pleased with how they came out. I'd already placed the holes for the hinge point on the tower, so now there are trays that latch into those holes, and, they fold up against the tower for storage. Just a couple of gotcha's tho. If you scale the tower to get a different size, the scaling must be uniform (scalex = scaley = scalez) or else the trays won't fit. The trays have to be scaled the same, of course. The only change to the tower, is the addition of catches, so that the trays snap and hold in place when folded. If you already printed a tower that you want to add trays to, well, you're out of luck on the catches. Note: Unlike the original, this is not available in customizer. Customizer has done more than anything to pollute Thingiverse to the point of unusability, and I will never use it. If you want to change the size, just use the scaling factors on your printer software.

First, don't try this in ABS without a heated chamber.  At 50C I still had some small cracks; at 52C, it printed perfectly.  I can't go much above that without an extruder clog (working on that).  A lower layer height may have helped too, but I was doing it at 0.25.  PLA should be fine. A low infil, 10% or less is all that's needed for the solid areas at the bottom of the tower.  
As I mentioned, use printer scaling to change the size.  The towers shown in the pictures were scaled up about 15% on all axes.

description.text: Just needed something to turn my endstop switch up and down.
An adjustable tensioner to keep the wheels firm, but not binding, in the vertical slots of a Delta style printer (Kossel, Griffin, Cerberus, etc.).

Printing with >20% infill should be sufficient.  Use M3 hardware for adjustments.  The scad file is attached so it can easily be scaled for other carriages.  
Use the screw to adjust the tension so there is no Non-Z movement but not too tight creating unwanted friction.

title: Change your stepper by a servo DC motor on Prusa i3 x-axis

description.text: I am studying the choices of using DC motors instead of steppers. This is my first example and I needed to attach the motor to an existing printer, this part did it. You can see the servo working before being installed in the printer in the next video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=jB6carTGRn8

This is the software I am running on an additional Arduino UNO: https://www.youmagine.com/designs/dc-motor-closed-loop-control-software And here it is the first print:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ekRmCNAKzP4&feature=youtu.be

comments.text:
Excellent idea. I was thinking about something like this.
Here are my questions/proposals:
comments.author: rklauco

comments.text:
RE: #5 -- if you do that, you will screw yourself for #3 (see below).
RE: #3 Static position is easy, if the rotary encoder clicks when it's not supposed to, fire the motor back in the other direction. -- That's the whole point of a closed loop system. -- Because it's geared, it means that there will not be a lot of slip in the final output (i.e. the amount of slip is the encoder resolution divided by your gear ratio). -- You could make that process a little more elegant by using something like PID as well.
comments.author: rklauco

comments.text: 6: A rotary or linear optical encoder from an old inkjet printer would be a better option. Most HP ones will have one of each and possibly one or two additional rotary ones if they have a built in scanner.
comments.author: rklauco

comments.text:
Hi Kadah,
You make an interesting point: measuring the linear output instead of the rotary shaft makes more sense to remove any backslash the mechanism could add. Inkjet printers use the optical pattern mostly to fire the dots and only loosely for position and speed control, as the head does long swings from side to side.
comments.author: Kadah

comments.text: The direct drive motor I was using simply didn't have enough poles for that level of positioning. If I turned up the Kp to insane levels, it helped a little for somewhat smaller movements (around 10 encoder pulses at best), but any corrective or sudden long movements (which really shouldn't happen when dealing with step input) were unstable and violent.

description.text:
Hi this is the first thing I'm uploading, he's my little desktop robot I
modelled him after the maker fair robot which I had downloaded and tried to print but the print failed as the joints all ended up fused solid so I designed my own that could be printer in parts and then
assembled so the joints would all work. I recommend printing with supports for everything but the body. A small note depending on your printer it may be necessary to either sand the rods or drill the joint holes out a little if done right then no glue should be needed to hold the pins in place, the head and arms just click in.

Print the body then the pins.  
Then print the legs.  
Assemble the legs first by attaching the feet to the shins then connect the shins to the upper leg finally connect the legs to the body with the long pin.  
For the arms start with the hands at the wrists with the thinnest rods then move up to the upper arm parts these attach with pins like the rest, finally the upper arms connect with a simple push fit connection.  
The head is another push fit connection that just clips in place  
Finally the key just plugs in the back.

I modified another version of this to fit wider tubes and made the slit
larger, this should work on most squeezable tubes.

Tooth paste squeezer, I modified it and made it a little longer and the
opening a little bit bigger so it can accommodate different width tubes. I used PLA set at 180c for the extruder and a heated bed at 65c with a extruding speed set to 110mm/s and non extrusion speed set to
150mm/s done at .20mm

Bracket to hold surplus 5-inch 8-diopter biconvex glass lens upright. Two versions: the one with ribs on the base support has less material, so should print faster. The lens is AllElectronics # LNS-65 http://www.allelectronics.com/make-a-store/item/lns-65/8-diopter-lens/1.html
This lens is heavy and not of great optical quality (as you can guess from the price) but OK for classroom optics demo. OpenSCAD files for lens holder are included.
This my second upload it's a grid for the YN560 speedlite it's a simple print that needs no support and works well at a 10% infill so it's light and soild

title: PrintrBox - a PrintrBot Simple Metal Enclosure

description.text:
Since my PrintrBot Simple Metal is printing almost non stop, I decided to build a 'simple' enclosure to dampen the sound a bit and moreover, keep it protected against any bumps or accidents during a print.   
To keep the size of the box as compact as possible I made a few cuts in the enclosure for the parts that can move when the machine is active.   
I cannot guarantee any significant noise reduction or improvement of prints due to the captured heat inside the box, but it sure does look nice :)

The Printrbox is made using 5 plates of lasercutted perspex (4mm), some 10mm m3 screws and 4 3D printed profiles using ColorFabb Standard Black 1.75mm PLA. The screws as seen on the photographs will be replaced by matte black m3's as soon as they arrive.   
The profiles are printed with a 20% infill at 200 microns. I added additional vertical and horizontal walls to keep it as strong as possible. (4 walls thick).   
Important to know: the holes are extruded with a diameter of 2.5 mm, so it is best to file/tap the holes before installing the PrintrBox. The depth of the holes is 9 mm in the 3D printed profile, so an M3 screw between 6-10 mm long will suffice when using 4mm perspex.

comments.text: Can anyone recommend a service which would cut perspex to the specifications in these files?  I've done an extensive Google search and have contacted several companies, but have run into several roadblocks.  I would like to get this enclosure created.

Fumes wise, it helps (I'm starting to use hairspray on a glass bed, so it stinks a lot less).

title: Drawbridge for wooden toy (Thomas) train set

description.text:
This is a drawbridge to fit Thomas the train wooden toy set. This is still work in progress. The design is fine, but I'm finding that, as printed, the whole bridge is so light that it moves around very easily. I separated out the ramp and bridge files from the bridge sides so one could print the sides in a different color (for better effect). Also, the scad file provides a testing parameter to allows you to see the whole thing assembled, OR to display it for printing. The ruler is there just for display. It requires tracklib.scad. Revisions:
  • reduced the clearance between the bridge and ramp
  • added pins to help fasten the railing to the bridge (still probably requires glue)

comments.text: The best way to get awesome fiber bridges is to use a small nozzle. I use a .25 nozzle and can strand all the way across my build platform diagonally (300mm). PLA is easier than ABS... but both work. There is a setting in Slic3r for bridging flow rate. If the strands start skinny and end fat then decrease the flow to get a nice even strand. The strands will sag as they print then tighten as they cool. Be careful with cooling because too much air will blow the strands around and make them stick to each other.

description.text: This is a filament spool clip in the form of a clamp that can generate a surprisingly firm grip.  The filament it is printed with must be extremely strong and able to flex slightly.  I used PETg, which is ideal for this application.

This design is as much of a test of the strength and flexibility of PETg as it is an actual useful filament spool clip.  Printed in PETg, it takes about 16 pounds force to open the clamp all the way, so its grip is quite strong.  If anyone prints this in a material other than PETg, I would like to know how it compares.  
I printed this with supports under the overhanging parts, with support structure dimensions set to 2mm.

author: darmach

description.text: I was just tinkering around with some custom mini parts and thought I'd share these.  A few variations on the same base.  I may upload more as time and ideas permit.

An updated version can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:251227. This is a robust, low mass extruder for 1.75 mm filament. It can be mounted to a vertical x axis with 70 mm spacing or can be mounted to a horizontal axis using the hot end mounting bolts. It is for the MakerGear hot end with the standard mounting pattern. The shaft is really milled rather than hobbed, which gives a much better "bite". It uses steel gears from Misumi which give a 5/1 gear ratio. The aluminum mounting plate acts as a heat sink, so fan cooling is unnecessary. This extruder/carriage is about 1/2 the weight of the original on the Aluminum Mendel, allowing for faster prints and smoother operation. Some weight comparisons to common extruders: gearExtruder - 311g (11 oz) Wade extruder - 549g (19.3 oz)
MakerGear 5 /1 - 457g (16.2 oz)
Minebea PG35L w/fan - 178g (6.3oz)

This project requires some metal working tools.  I used my MicroMill to cut the aluminum back plate, hot end mounting plate, and the hobbed shaft.  These can be done by hand if you are very careful.  Print out the alumPlate Template and use it as a drill guide. I originally used a #4-40 tap to hob the shaft, but I had much better results milling the shaft.  I will post a fixture for milling the shaft soon.
I recommend setting the retraction length to .5 mm and the retraction speed to 15 mm/s in Slic3r to avoid skipping steps on filament retraction at high print speeds.

An improvised ocarina design - to my surprise, it worked on the first try. Cut from a 3.5 x 11.5 inch slab of 1/4" maple. Check the video to hear what it sounds like: http://www.flickr.com/photos/ranjit/5423038441/ With the finger holes on the sides instead of the top, it's not as easy to play as my previous ocarina: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1816 - but it's way easier to assemble. This is part of my project to make a crude musical instrument every day in February. (More at moonmilk.com)

Cut from 1/4" wood or maybe acrylic - I don't know if an acrylic version works, but it probably would. If you cut from 1/8" material, you might try cutting two of each layer and doubling up. This ocarina was scaled to fit a 3.5 x 11.5 inch piece of wood. It should work larger or smaller, but if you make it much bigger, I suggest reducing the relative sizes of the finger holes so that they're not too big to easily cover with your fingers. Using appropriate glue, assemble the layers in two halves as shown in http://www.thingiverse.com/image:42408 - it's important that the layers be airtight, so be generous with glue. Glue the two halves together, and you have an ocarina!

This is meant for checking your calibration, slicer settings, etc. I created it as a way to confirm my suspicions about my slicer software not printing certain parts correctly.   
The holes are 3mm, 10mm and 15mm, the pins are 2.5mm, 9.5mm and 14.5mm, so they should all fit together nicely. If there is interference or excessive play, something is wrong.   
Designed in Autodesk Inventor and exported as a high resolution STL.
I did mine with PLA at 0.2mm layer height, 20% infill and 100mm/s print speed. Took 19-21 minutes depending on slicing program.

remixed_from.author: GiulianoM
remixed_from.title: NEMA17 Sub-Micro Servo Bracket for Auto Bed Leveling

title: Servo Bracket with 60mm LED light ring mount and remixed parts

description.text:
The original bracket is great, but my Prusa i3 uses a short (36oz.in.) NEMA 17 stepper, placing the servo too close to (touching) my hot end. I redesigned the top clamp to accommodate the stepper plug, thus allowing me to move the bracket to the back of the stepper. I also shortened the switch arm to the minimum length that would fold up beside the bracket, and I modified the recess for the servo horn to accommodate the non-tapered single horn that came with my 9g. servo. The horn simply glues into place with the screw side exposed for removal if needed.  
Another change was adding arms to support a 60mm LED ring. The ring is attached to the bracket using two zip ties, which holds the ring flat and securely. (You MUST insulate the top of the LED ring to prevent heat from the individual LEDs from weakening the arms. See updates in the instructions.)  
See the drawings and photos!

I printed the items in the photos using black PLA, 0.3mm layers, solid fill, with extruder at 200C and bed at 50C. The LED ring is from ebay (search for 60mm Angel Eyes) and has 15LEDs, operating at 12v. It is attached to the bracket with two zip ties.  
UPDATE 01/03/2015: After a long duration print job, the heat from the bed caused the LED arms to droop. I updated the design to include some support beneath the arms as well as a few holes to help cooling.   
UPDATE 01/072015: The dropping arms was not caused by heat radiating from the heated bed or the hot end. After replacing the clamp with the updated version I inspected the old one and found swells in the PLA above each of the LEDs in the ring. They are obviously the cause of the heat-related failure of the arms. I have insulated the LED ring using silicone impregnated fiberglass material and have had no further problems. Either design (holes/no holes) should work fine -David

comments.text: How do you keep your hotend from warping the auto leveler arm?
comments.author: Randman77

comments.text: I insulated my hotend block with siliconized woven fiberglass wrapped with kapton tape. This keeps the radiated heat down to a minimum and increases the efficiency of the block by keeping the heat inside where it belongs. I also installed a large aluminum washer right above the hot end to further dissipate heat that rises from the block onto the filament throat. Now, my cold end block is actually cooling the throat enough that filament jams are a thing of the past as well!
comments.author: Randman77

comments.text: Well, I don't have any of that fancy fiberglass stuff, but I wrapped my heater block with normal fiberglass insulation (the kind in the walls of your house) and kapton tape. I still had some warping, so I spun the heater block 180 degrees so that the heat cartridge is now on the side opposite from the servo arm (towards the front of the printer). That seems to have solved the problem, but for peace of mind I insulated the arm too, and now it's all good! Soon I will reprint the parts in ABS, then I shouldn't have to insulate the servo arm.

title: Dust Blower accessory for Dremel 4000 CNC mount

description.text: Converts a 40mm fan (with roughly 23-25mm center hub) into a radial fan weighing 22 grams. Everything can be printed without support, just rotate them because my STL files are always sideways. I suck at making parts that fit together (and many printers do too) so this is all glue together, except for the fan itself. The blades are springy to accommodate multiple hub sizes, and the included adapter ring can be used on smaller hubs. I have also included my cooling shroud for attaching to the end of the fan to cool both the print and the cold end of the extruder. Mine moves much more air than the fan it came from, and makes less noise. See instructions for details.

The Motor Mount glues to the outside of the Bottom (or Top, depending on the motor's rotation) and the motor (which you have to break out of its circular mount, and break the blades off of) gets glued to this. The Fan gets compression fit on the motor's hub (or onto the adapter ring) and then the top gets glued on. See the photo with the green mousepad for a fully assembled fan, and the other photo of one mounted to a printer with the included shroud. Good luck!

comments.text: I will release an update to this soon, the fan tends to blow air out of the sides under pressure, which can hurt ABS prints.

This is a filament spool holder for the Velleman Vertex 3D printer (K8400). No support material needed (at least for PLA printed parts). The STL edition is for a spool holder with the following dimensions:
  • Spool hole diameter: 31 mm
  • Spool width: 77 mm
  • Spool hole "side" width: 4 mm
    • This corresponds to Innofil3D spools (at least the three spools of theirs I own). The spool holder can be assembled with 4 M3 bolts and nuts or with a cable tie, wire or equivalent wound around the middle (the latter is not tested). Please see instructions for information on how to change dimensions to your need or leave a comment with requests for other dimensions, then I'll see what I can do.

You need to print two of these parts (obviously). I sliced them with Cura, 0.2 mm layer height, 10% infill - which seems to be enough for 1 kg spools - PLA, no support and standard slow Vertex setting which took a little more than an hour to print (per piece). Assemble the parts using 4 M3 bolts (preferable with flat heads, length less than or equal to 10 mm) and corresponding 4 M3 nuts or simply a cable tie or similar around the middle (not tested). Included is also the Cubify Invent file used to generate the model. Change the following parameters in order to use other filament spools:
  • SpoolWidth
  • SpoolHoleDiameter
  • SpoolSideWidth

comments.text:
I made this years ago for my K8400 Vertex and it's my only spool holder. I recently made this slide-on adapter to fit bigger 1 kg spools conveniently:

description.text:
Y.A.M.A.R. == Yet Another MeArm Remix This is a remix of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:616239 These are my improvements to MeArm ostensibly becuase it is being printed and not laser cut from an A4 sheet of Acrylic. The intent is to remain as compatible with the original MeArm 0.4 as possible. This would allow a set of additional parts that an original MeArm owner could pick and choose from to have printed and add to their MeArm. Due to this being printed, I have made improvements involving shapes that can't be laser cut (i.e. thicker than 3mm) as well as additional parts that would push the original MeArm material usage outside the A4 acyrlic envelope. Some improvements:
  • Larger servos (different sizes er application)
  • Avoidance of needed to tap screws in the material itself for fixing (rely instead on nuts and bots with nylon nuts).
  • Extra parts to stablise and avoid backlash
    • In the photos, parts in Red are the improved parts. Blue are standard MeArm 0.4.

Pensando y pensando como disminuir la vibración de mi printrbot -.- no llegue muy lejos XD. Pero bueno me inspiré en esta idea http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:562832 Aun hay algunas piezas que requieren un par de ajustes o un poco de trabajo así que tenganlo en mente, cualquier pregunta con mucho gusto http://youtu.be/iUiEkg5DiiI Update 18/01/2015
changed y_stop_block IMPORTANT: READ INSTRUCCTION FIRST!!! NOTA MUY IMPORTANTE: Si quieren hacer esto necesitaran barras mucho más grandes para el eje y, esto se pensó para reducir vibraciones sin cuidar el espacio así que las barras originales no sirven porque son muy pequeñas. 25cm en adelante estaría bien y van a necesitar unos 50cm mucho 60cm de faja(GT2-belt)

De seguro va a necesitar un taladro, una broca gruesa y un poco de lija(sand paper), ya que los agujeros son un poco ajustados demasiado ajustados tanto para las barras de 8mm como para los roles lineales(linear bearrings), solo arrollen un poco de lija en la broca y el resto es historia XD. Cuidado con no lijar demasiado ya que igual tienen que entrar con algo de fuerza, solo se quiere quitar las imperfexiones que quedan por imprimir Todas las tuercas se calientan un poco y con eso entran bien. Por el momento van a necesitar un poco de superbonder(super glue) para unir las piezas que sostienen el ventilador y el sensor del ejej z La pieza multiplatform_mount es mejor imprimirla rotada 90 grados, para que no requiera soportes ya que con ellos no se porta muy bien, no aconsejo que usen soportes en esta pieza No hay huecos para el final de carrera del eje y esto para que puedan ajustarlo ustedes, así es más fácil que imprimirlos ya que son huecos muy pequeños. El hot-end se monta sobre un pedazo de plywood de 9mm voy a dibujar la pieza para que sepan donde van los huecos, aunque creo que sería mejor si corren el hod-end un poco hacia atras porque en donde yo lo puse se como un poco del eje y Es necesario que compren al menos 10 tornillos de los grandes, del mismo tipo que trae la printrbor Y este es el gear gt2 que utilice http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:280522 aunque imprimirlo es un poco dificil, yo ocupé un nuzzel de 0.2mm igual pueden hacer algo mil veces más simple, yo le puse en medio uno de los roles que sobran de la misma impresora Que necesita mejorarse!!!(What needs improvement)
y_belt y y_belt_v3 no son muy buenas formas de sujetar la faja, por lo que creo que debo mejorar tambien la pieza multiplatform_mount_v3. Luego sensors_and_fan_mount_v2 es un hecho que está totalmente en desarrollo, tengo que hacer entradas para las piezas fan_part para especificar en donde van y no tener que pegarlas a puro cálculo

title: Spindle Vacuum Adapter For Portalcyclone CNC

description.text: Vacuum spindle adapter for http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:238329 and maybe others using Adapter #1 from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:536091 The spindle mount from the CNC vacuum mount and adapter doesn't really work with the portal cyclone cnc. The vacuum tube is too high and the 52mm clamp design made the Z axis travel shorter. Long story short, The adapters needed help. On my 400 watt spindle, there was a 4x34mm bolt circle on the bottom which is a great mounting spot for the portalcyclone. I also designed a hose support to help as a strain relief on the vacuum hose.

Printed from PLA. The Adapter #1 should be printed with a LH .15mm (per the original instructions). The rest of the pieces can be printed with a .3mm LH and 25%+ infill. My spindle had 4mm holes tapped so I used 4x10mm screws to hold the vacuum adapter in place.

Keep your pickle** safe and happy.  
I've seen lots of utensils for peaches / passion fruit, but nothing for pickles.  Now you can hold your pickle without getting pickle juice everywhere.  Works even better if someone holds it for you.  
** Keep pictures of "makes" clean.  No body wants to see your pickle.

This is untested and likely to not work at all.  
If you print the inner part in PLA or ABS it is likely to be more like a pickle skinner.  
Ninjaflex probably won't work either, it's more like Vinyl than silicon or rubber.  TPU might be an option as it is flexible and resistant to oil and abrasion.

I switched over to a 3/8-20 threaded rod for my Z-Axis, and the delrin nut that was included is for the 3/8-18 ACME rod. It does not fit. I had a really crude solution, but then I looked on here for something better. I couldn't find anything that would work for me, so I drew up a quick sketch to try out.   
Print two, put the nut inside, and then install where the delrin nut was.

Print 2 of them, in PLA preferably.   
Add nut inside.  
Screw them together, and into the existing delrin nut holder on your z carriage.  
You will probably need to drill out the holes for the screws to fit perfectly.   
You can use a light flame to soften the plastic to help the nut get in as tight as possible.
Fixed the 4mm glass door hook to not throw a manifold error in Repetier.  I am using this as a prototype glass drawer pull. Thanks to lucibrandus for the original!

description.text: My dad wanted a tunnel for our Lionel Train Set, so I designed one in Blender! Video demo is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=O_qTKXkKmnA&feature=youtu.be This tunnel is 224mm wide, 290mm long, and 140mm tall. It is split into two pieces, both of which require the entire build volume of the MakerBot Replicator Dual! It has a guaranteed clearance height of 110mm and width of 90mm, plus a curved ceiling which adds up to 20mm additional clearance height depending on the object traveling under it. The platform above can completely fit an object with a blueprint of 160mm x 210mm, but actually has more room due to the mountainous structure. The tunnel also has a 70mm diameter hole at the top in case you need to fit a plug to power any decorations on top.

Print both pieces of the tunnel***.Print settings are up to you, but this is what I did: MakerBot Desktop PLA LOW Resolution (Fastest) print settings, except with 5% infill:
Layer Height: 0.3mm
Shells: 2
Infill: 5%
Support: YES
Rafts: NO
(I also like to keep my build plate at 40C) Build time was around 13.5 hours for each piece. Even though MakerBot Desktop projected needing almost 2 lbs of filament, it seems the actual print required less, seeing how my 2lb filament spool has 15-20% plastic left. I created two holes that can be fitted with pins to join the tunnel, but I think using glue may be easier. ***I added "no holes" versions of the two tunnel pieces. These versions don't have cylindrical holes on the inside walls. I had originally put those holes there to allow for connecting using pins, but removing these holes may allow you to use 0% infill to save on plastic. Then, simply glue the pieces together using a crazy glue or Loctite super glue (or anything else that is good at bonding your plastic together)

description.text:
This is a simple diffuser that pops on top of the 5mm LED solderless holder made by roipoussiere (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:170562). Also pictured is an excellent design by Elwin (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:597501) Please see instructions if you have troubles. Included the Blender file so you may hash it up as you will. If you print it, please let me know how it turned out.
If you rework it, please share your creations and make a mention of its origins. If you like what you see please feel free to leave a tip: http://modernwebsitesolutions.com/resources/tipjar.html Thanks

Used Cura slicer: Spiralize Contour = Checked
Shell Thinkness = 0.7
Top/Bottom Thickness = 0.7
Solid Bottom Infill = Unchecked
Layer Height = 0.4 I've tried to go with the lowest temp as possible running a cooling fan on the print head after the first layer was laid, and run it slow. If it turns out to be a bit too small or large, try playing with either the shell thickness or can scale it.
